entries.title: Iowa Birth and Early Years
entries.description: Lindy Achen began his life in 1902, born in Remsen, Iowa. This period marks his earliest memories, setting the stage for a childhood that would soon transition to a new life on the Canadian prairies. He was just a baby during this time, unaware of the significant changes his family would soon undertake.

excerpts.text: and go back and start relating the story from where I was born at Remsen, Iowa, October the 7th, 1902.

entries.title: Early Years: Iowa and Saskatchewan
entries.description: These early years, from 1905 to 1907, represent a period of foundational experiences for Lindy. He was a young boy in Iowa before his family embarked on a significant journey to Saskatchewan, Canada. This move would shape his life and future as a farmer on the prairies.

excerpts.text: - be a long drawn-out affair as my memory goes back to the year 1907 when
And now we're talking into 1905.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Work and Growth
entries.description: From 1911 to 1916, young Lindy Achen experienced the demanding life of a farm boy on the Canadian prairies. He worked alongside his family, contributing to building projects like a new barn and pasture, and enduring long days of physical labor. These years shaped his work ethic and established a rhythm of hard work that would define much of his life.

excerpts.text: he put down the foundation everything then we had to haul all those rock in to fill that foundation in and then filled it up with sand so they could put a four inch coat of cement all over the barn it was an up-to-date barn everything was first class. That's when I was 13 years old that fall, the fall of 1915. You want to know about work, well that was work and that same
And as soon as we were able to work, I can remember when they built that pasture in 1914, I guess it was, that they used to haul us a mile and a half away, and we'd dig post holes all day
That would take us through the years of about 1916, '17, I'd say, somewhere in there.
In the summer when I was, what, 1915, I was 13 years old that fall.
I think it was the winter of '16 when J.P. was married.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Shadows and Short Crops
entries.description: For Lindy, 1917 was a difficult year, marked by short harvests and a sense of unease. He was a teenager living and working on the family farm in Saskatchewan, experiencing the hardships of prairie life alongside his brothers. The year 1918 brought the devastating influenza pandemic, further shaping his memories of this formative period.

excerpts.text: Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
That would take us through the years of about 1916, '17, I'd say, somewhere in there.
And that's all it takes through '17, 1918, still home on the farm.
Then, '17 is a short crop, '18 was a short crop.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Flu and Tractors
entries.description: In 1918, sixteen-year-old Lindy Achen continued to work on his family's farm in Saskatchewan, facing a short harvest and the devastating impact of the influenza pandemic which arrived in the spring. His father purchased a Titan tractor during this time, marking a shift in farm technology, while the family relied on livestock and resourcefulness to survive the challenging conditions.

excerpts.text: 1918 short crop. 1919 less crop again but we always fared somehow we had a lot of always raised 50 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around so we had our own eggs our own pork had our own beef we always had 50 60 head of cattle and about that many horses so you're never short on work
Around about that time went fast, 1917, 1917, that was the year, no 1918 was when the flu hit.
And Dad bought a... Oh, in the meantime, 1918, he had bought a little Titan tractor.
And that's all it takes through '17, 1918, still home on the farm.
That was '18, and '19 we dried out, totally dried out.

entries.title: Prairie Hardship and Grasshopper Years
entries.description: During 1919-1920, seventeen and eighteen-year-old Lindy Achen experienced significant agricultural challenges on the family farm in Saskatchewan. Years of drought severely impacted crop yields, compounded by a devastating grasshopper infestation in 1920 that nearly wiped out their harvest, despite the family's efforts to maintain livestock and self-sufficiency.

excerpts.text: 1918 short crop. 1919 less crop again but we always fared somehow we had a lot of always raised 50 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around so we had our own eggs our own pork had our own beef we always had 50 60 head of cattle and about that many horses so you're never short on work
But in the end, you got very little crop out of it. It was probably five bushel to the acre so and that took us through '20. '21, a good crop a good crop that could ...
In 1920, the grasshoppers came in, and they just really come in clouds, you know, ... poison a whole quarter section.
1920, the hoppers came in and just about cleaned us out.
That was '18, and '19 we dried out, totally dried out.

entries.title: Prairie Harvest and Changing Times
entries.description: In 1921, nineteen-year-old Lindy was deeply involved in farm work in Saskatchewan, running the thrashing outfit and experiencing a relatively good harvest after a difficult 1920. This year also marked significant changes: his father acquired new equipment, a family member (Joe) left for the coast, and Lindy experienced the novelty of radio, all while sharing the farm with his brother Mac.

excerpts.text: But in the end, you got very little crop out of it. It was probably five bushel to the acre so and that took us through '20. '21, a good crop a good crop that could ...
And then it was the fall of '21. Dad bought a little separator to go with the little Titan tractor we had.
And as it was then, that was '21. Then that fall, Joe left. He went to the coast.
I was running the thrashing outfit, and I run that same outfit then in 1921.
So Mac and I were home alone on the farm then through '21, '22.

entries.title: Prairie Harvest and Early Learning
entries.description: During 1922-1923, Lindy was a young man of 20-21, living and working on the family farm in Saskatchewan. This period was marked by bountiful harvests and a focus on practical skills, including taking a telephone course to maintain the family's rural telephone system. It also saw his mother's departure for California and potentially his first experience with radio.

excerpts.text: In the winter of '22, I came to Regina and took a telephone course in order to be able to maintain the telephones at home, the local rural telephone.
Maybe later than that, it could have been '22 or '23, I heard my first radio.
Maybe later than that, it could have been '22 or '23, I heard my first radio.
And the winter of twenty - the fall of '23, mother went to California.
So Mac and I were home alone on the farm then through '21, '22.

entries.title: Loss, Farm, and New Responsibility
entries.description: 1924 was a pivotal year for Lindy, marked by the sudden death of his father. He immediately assumed responsibility for the family farm in Saskatchewan, beginning his first year as its primary operator. This period was also a time of significant transition and likely emotional upheaval for the young man.

excerpts.text: mother,  mother got there by train it's funny how you could move around in those days. She'd come all the way from portland and we only held the funeral two days, I think. She was there for the funeral. And then I was in charge of the farm starting right then and there so that was in 1924 and uh
I have a few minutes to go before I go for coffee, so I'll just continue about the years before 1924.
I'm getting the story a bit mixed up, but I'll go back to 1924.
That was the summer of 1924, my first year of running the farm.
And, oh yes, in '24, in '24, yeah, we had finished.

entries.title: Prairie Roots, Power's Early Spark
entries.description: From 1925 to 1930, Lindy experienced a period of agricultural prosperity followed by significant change. Leaving the family farm after disagreements, he transitioned into the electrical field, beginning his career in power line construction and laying the groundwork for his future company, Achen Construction. These years marked a shift from rural farming life to a burgeoning career in a rapidly developing industry.

excerpts.text: Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -

Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -
I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
'26, some of the boys came up from California, and they thought Mother was paying me too much money.
The old line, which had been built in 1928, we had a salvage 60 miles a line.

entries.title: Prairie Years: Work and Transition
entries.description: Between 1931 and 1934, Lindy Achen navigated a period of fluctuating employment, initially working for the Power Commission before taking a leave of absence and returning to the family farm. He pursued electrical work, including inside wiring and later gaining experience in Gull Lake, while also facing periods of unemployment and travel to Tompkins, laying the groundwork for his future construction business.

excerpts.text: And when I think back through the years from about '31 when I started working for the Power Commission, and I mentioned that earlier, and then I only worked for them eight months, and I took a leave of absence and I never went back.
It was in 1934 that the electrician - the inspector who used to come through there said to me one day, "Why don't you write your journeyman's paper?" he said, "You're a good electrician."
And then the spring of '34, Dubois, the superintendent, this was still the same company that was in Estevan, he said, "I'm putting you down in Gull Lake to do some wiring there.
So I worked in the summer of '34, '35, part of '33 at 50 cents an hour, and paid my own room and board.
So I worked in the summer of '34, '35, part of '33 at 50 cents an hour, and paid my own room and board.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Changing Lines
entries.description: From 1935 to 1939, Lindy Achen worked as an electrician and power plant operator in Saskatchewan, initially managing a small plant before its abandonment due to the construction of a new power line. He then took on responsibilities overseeing power lines and calibrating meters, traveling between locations like Shaunavon and Gravelbourg, marking a period of transition and expanding his skills within the electrical field.

excerpts.text: Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -

Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -

Well, I operated that for about a year and a half and then the company saw fit to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins and shut that down. Now we're into 1930 we're into 1930 - yeah I operated the plant '35, '36 into the spring of '37 and uh -
And then in '36, they decided they were going to run a power line from Gull Lake to Tompkins, and abandoned this little power plant.
In the spring of '38, I went out and relieved out at Gravelbourg in Lafleche while they changed operators out there.

entries.title: Marriage, Work, and Constant Alert
entries.description: From 1940 to 1944, Lindy Achen was married and deeply involved in his construction business, likely related to electrical infrastructure. This period was marked by intense on-call work, often 24/7, and the construction of a new airport in Estevan, Saskatchewan, indicating a time of significant professional demands and likely wartime-related activity.

excerpts.text: And they were building an airport in Estevan, around '42, and ... one hell of a place to work.
Then the airport came in in 1941, so it was really a busy time around there.
Then I was in charge of the lines there for the rest of '37, '38, '39, '40.
And there's '41, '42, '43, '44, on call, 24 hours a day, 30 days a month.
And there's '41, '42, '43, '44, on call, 24 hours a day, 30 days a month.

entries.title: Prairie Contractor: Building a Future
entries.description: 1945 marked a significant shift for Lindy Achen, as he transitioned to independent contracting and began building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He was actively bidding on projects and working closely with individuals like Ted Durnan, establishing his construction business. This period, extending into 1946 and beyond, saw him solidify his reputation as a key contractor in the region.

excerpts.text: The tenders ranged - now this is in 1945 dollars. You can multiply that by five for today. The first tender opened up, $11,000; the next one, $11,500; the next one, $11,075, and then mine was the last one, $10,050. Well here I was just
I started working on power in 1927, and then I worked until just about the end of '45 for various companies.
The Fall of '45, when I finished the airport, I came into Regina here and did some work.
I'll give you a history of my years of contracting, which was from 1945 to 1965.
Now I'm a contractor on my own, and the time is the end of September 1945.

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Labor
entries.description: The years 1946-1950 were a period of significant expansion for Lindy's Achen Construction, as he focused on building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He oversaw a large project to Stoughton and dealt with labor disputes involving strikes among his workers. This era marked a period of growth and challenge for his burgeoning construction business.

excerpts.text: ,in those days, I'm talking back in 1946, up to 1950, I had a bunch go on strike up - way up north of Swift Current.
We're talking now the end of 1945 and 1946, the '46 -
We're talking now the end of 1945 and 1946, the '46 -
I built that big line to Stoughton in '46.
Yes, I even did some in 1945 or '46.

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Running Crews
entries.description: In 1947, Lindy Achen was 45 years old and deeply involved in expanding rural electrification across Saskatchewan. He was managing multiple construction crews, building power lines between towns like Weyburn, Radville, and Trossachs, and overseeing the completion of seasonal projects. This year marked a significant period of growth and responsibility for Achen Construction.

excerpts.text: 1947, my first job was building a line from Weyburn to Radville and picking up the village of Trossachs on the way.
And as the funny says - Fools Hesitate, Funny McGee. Well, that was the end of 1947.
There's no interference from the wind, so I'll go on talking about 1947 now.
And I want to go back now to 1947, when I was running the two crews.
to finish up at Yorkton from the fall of '47.

entries.title: Shifting Gears, New Directions
entries.description: 1948 appears to be a pivotal year for Lindy Achen, marked by a sense of needing to 'make definite moves' and significant reflection on his work. He was actively involved in his construction business, likely tendering for projects and finishing existing work, while also relocating his family to Regina, Saskatchewan. The year seems to represent a period of transition and reevaluation for him.

excerpts.text: and moved up here. It was still spring there was a lot of snow I think we come up about - maybe about the end of march or the middle of april sometime in there we moved to Regina. Now, I didn't have any work for '48 we had to tender. Well I still had a little work to finish up at Rosetown and a little
The spring of 1948, I could see then things were going to move ahead, and I had to make some definite moves.
The price had been established back in, when, '50 - '48 or '50, somewhere in there, had been established.
And I have to really think hard now to think of where I worked in '48. In '48...
And I have to really think hard now to think of where I worked in '48. In '48...

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Alberta Winds
entries.description: In 1949, Lindy Achen and Achen Construction were actively expanding rural power lines across Saskatchewan, Canada. His work took him to Alberta at times, involving projects like securing a high-voltage line from Killaly. The year was marked by a flurry of activity, moving between farm electrification and other construction projects.

excerpts.text: Another time we had built a line up in Alberta, I may have said that earlier. And Art Miller was up there. This was way back in '49.
And in '49, I went to - oh yeah, I got the piece of high voltage line, the 72,000 from Killaly,
Previous to that, in '49, I can't recollect where we were working.
From there, moved down to - oh, I forgot to tell you, in '49.
Well, anyway, that was the start of '49. Now I have -

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Union Roots
entries.description: The year 1950 marked a period of intense activity for Lindy Achen and Achen Construction, as they expanded their power line work across Saskatchewan, including significant projects near Rosetown, Ogema, and Yorkton. This year also saw the beginnings of a contractors' union, reflecting the challenges and evolving landscape of the construction industry, and Lindy was actively involved in negotiating and building these lines.

excerpts.text: anything that come up no matter what it was. And they let the other guys get by. Some of them set up little one-horse offices but didn't have anybody in there to man it, so they were no better off but that was one of the things they asked for and never got. But I don't know to relate back - Oh, we had a contractors' union. We started that way back in about 1950.

And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogema–Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
And that wound her up to '50 - '51. We went up north in the Rosetown area and we had a big job up there, a lot of three-phase transmission line and about probably
Then in '50, I started out. Built that line from Yorkton to Theodore and from there, Lampman to Bienfait, that was another 18 miles.
,in those days, I'm talking back in 1946, up to 1950, I had a bunch go on strike up - way up north of Swift Current.

entries.title: Prairie Lines and Busy Years
entries.description: The years 1950-1951 were a period of intense work for Lindy Achen and his construction company. He and his team were building extensive three-phase transmission lines and power lines across Saskatchewan, covering significant distances and servicing numerous towns. It was a 'big season' marked by substantial projects and a heavy workload.

excerpts.text: And then down in the Ogema - Shaunavon area, yeah, Fife Lake, and in that area we did a bunch of towns there in '50, '51, we were in the Ogema–Bengough, and in through there we did 60 or 70 miles of line in a bunch of towns.
And that wound her up to '50 - '51. We went up north in the Rosetown area and we had a big job up there, a lot of three-phase transmission line and about probably
I set all the poles in all the suburbs that were built from 1951.
Yeah, then '51, then I got a whole bunch of line.
Big season that was in '51.

entries.title: Wiring the Prairie Farms
entries.description: In 1952, Lindy Achen's construction company began a significant expansion of rural power lines across Saskatchewan. This period marked a rapid increase in farm connections, with the company building hundreds of lines and substations each year. Lindy, at age 50, was deeply involved in the intense, often challenging work of electrifying the prairies.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
We were out building all these lines in from - starting about '52 is when the farm program really started.
We got so much a pole, so much an anchor, so much a transformer, from 1952 through to 1957.
Then we really swung into the farm building in '52, '53.
And then '52 - and then the farms started picking up.

entries.title: Incorporation and Rapid Growth
entries.description: 1953 marked a pivotal year for Lindy Achen, as he incorporated his business and experienced significant expansion in his rural electrification work. He rapidly scaled his operations, building new facilities that quickly proved too small, and oversaw a substantial increase in the number of farms connected to power. This period was characterized by intense work and a focus on growth, despite initial uncertainties about his own compensation.

excerpts.text: five or six years when I - when I incorporated and I never did change my wages then in the - from '53 to '65 in 12 years I still took $1,000 a month, but I was taking up big bonuses at the end of the year -
And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
I built an office and a shop in '53, and it was too small the day I built it, and it's still operating.
And when I incorporated then in 1953, I didn't know what wages I should draw.
Then we really swung into the farm building in '52, '53.

entries.title: Prairie Expansion and Power Lines
entries.description: Around 1954, Lindy's Achen Construction was experiencing rapid growth, significantly expanding the number of farms they electrified each year. This period was marked by intense work building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, alongside memorable weather events like a devastating sleet storm that crippled communication in Manitoba.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
Oh, in 1954, they had a big sleet storm in Manitoba, and they took down all the telephone lines in southern Manitoba.
That was the pace we were hitting in '53, '54, '55
It was '54.

entries.title: Powering the Prairie, A Sudden Stop
entries.description: The mid-1950s were a period of intense expansion for Achen Construction, with the company rapidly increasing the number of farms connected to rural power lines. Lindy, at 53, was deeply involved in this work, driving the company's momentum until a heart attack abruptly halted his progress. This event marked a significant turning point in his career and life.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
In '55, when I had my heart attack, you know, I was right out of it.
And '55, well, we did some towns and villages in that, too.
That was the pace we were hitting in '53, '54, '55
And I wasn't - In '55 and '56

entries.title: Powering the Prairie Landscape
entries.description: The mid-1950s were a period of significant expansion for Achen Construction, as Lindy and his team dramatically increased the number of farms they electrified across Saskatchewan. Lindy, in his early fifties, oversaw a surge in productivity, consistently exceeding previous years' achievements and pushing the company to new heights. This era marked a peak in his career building rural power lines.

excerpts.text: And we were punching through, I think, at '52, about 350 farms, and then we jumped up to 500 or better every year for '53, '54, '55, '56.
And it went up to about 450 farms in '56.
I think we did about 600 farms in '56.
started about 1956 or 7, about '57.
We wound up, again, '56 more farms.

entries.title: Tapering Down, Filling In
entries.description: Around 1957, Lindy's farm operation was winding down, transitioning from large-scale work to more scattered tasks. His company, Achen Construction, had been heavily involved in building rural power lines since 1952, but activity began to decrease around this time. Lindy continued to oversee operations, employing Art Miller to manage the shop.

excerpts.text: '57 now the farm operation the big units of 40 and 50 farms are pretty well all done. We're doing a scattered filling -
We got so much a pole, so much an anchor, so much a transformer, from 1952 through to 1957.
And I just finished saying that we were - in '57, we were filling in farms.
Well, after '57, I kept Art Miller in the shop to more or less
Then in '57, it started tapering down.

entries.title: Dust Settles, Business Shifts
entries.description: 1958 appears to have been a challenging year for Lindy, marked by a lack of work and being 'bit out' of projects, suggesting business setbacks. He was actively expanding his office and dealing with the aftermath of events, with most of his team based in Regina, indicating a period of transition and reorganization within Achen Construction.

excerpts.text: Yeah, when the dust was settled in '58, well, I had my men, most of them were in Regina here.
Well, anyway, to get back to '58, when I was bid right out, didn't have any work.
I expanded the office in 1958, I think it was,
When they opened their wide up in '58,
And I'm still talking back in '58.

entries.title: Prairie Power, A Quiet Year
entries.description: 1959 appears to be a transitional year for Lindy Achen, following a period of activity with his construction company. While he struggled to recall specific events, it seems to have marked a completion of some project or phase, though he described it as unremarkable. It falls within his period of building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, a significant undertaking in his life.

excerpts.text: And the next year, in '59, things started picking up again.
In '59, what did we do in 59?
Yeah, '59 was not a big year.
And we kept going, '59 -
And that completed '59.

entries.title: Building Lines, Bidding, and Years
entries.description: The early 1960s were a busy time for Lindy and Achen Construction, focused on building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He and his team were actively bidding on projects, including a significant high-voltage line, and consistently working to expand their network, though memories of the details become increasingly hazy as the years progressed.

excerpts.text: Then in '61, Rags Johnson and ourselves jointly bid on a piece of high-voltage line from Shellbrook to Prince Albert, which had a river crossing in it, which was always a big job.
Then '63. Trying to think, in '63 - as the later years come come in it's harder for me to remember what the hell we were doing. And -
Then '63. Trying to think, in '63 - as the later years come come in it's harder for me to remember what the hell we were doing. And -
And then Con Bandy, another guy that started working for me in '63, or '62, somewhere in there.
And then Con Bandy, another guy that started working for me in '63, or '62, somewhere in there.

entries.title: Prairie Power and Passing Years
entries.description: The years 1963 and 1964 found Lindy deeply involved in his construction business, continuing the work of building rural power lines across Saskatchewan. He was in his early sixties, reflecting on a life shaped by farming, family disputes, and the satisfaction of bringing electricity to remote communities. These years likely marked a transition point as his work began to wind down.

excerpts.text: That was '63 and '64.

entries.title: Retirement and Achen Construction
entries.description: The years surrounding 1965 marked a significant shift for Lindy Achen, as he sold his interests in Achen Construction and formally retired from a lifetime of building rural power lines. He felt burned out and transitioned into a new chapter, though the company continued under Art's leadership with a name referencing the year of Lindy's departure. This period also involved a period of consistent income prior to his retirement.

excerpts.text: five or six years when I - when I incorporated and I never did change my wages then in the - from '53 to '65 in 12 years I still took $1,000 a month, but I was taking up big bonuses at the end of the year -
I've enjoyed relatively good health, considering that when I quit, I - when I quit in 1965, I was pretty well burned out.
With Art - they set up a company, Achen '65 Limited, and Art was the 51% shareholder.
I'll give you a history of my years of contracting, which was from 1945 to 1965.
No strings attached." Except they made it Achen Construction, 1965 Limited.

entries.title: Retreat and Reflection
entries.description: Around 1966, Lindy Achen was transitioning out of the construction business, selling off his company between 1965 and 1967. This marked a significant shift after decades of building rural power lines across Saskatchewan, likely prompting a period of reflection and reassessment at the age of 64.

excerpts.text: This is in '66 - yeah that's -
I sold out in '65, '66, '67.
